sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
A new species of Placospongia is described from Bahia State , Brazil . Placospongia giseleae sp. nov. . The specimen is found on the underside of rocks in shallow waters ( 0-20m ), and is unique by having a spiculation consisting of two tylostyle categories, selenasters and acanthomicrorhabds. In addition, Placospongia ruetzleri , is recorded for the first time to Bahia state , 2.974 km southwards from its type locality, the Guyana shelf. The diversity of Placospongia species
is raised from two to four taxa. An identification key for Western Atlantic Placospongia species
is presented.
Key words: Taxonomy, sponges, Clionaida , Brazil

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Placospongiidae Gray, 1867 belongs to the Order
Clionaida Morrow & Cárdenas (2015) , and is composed by three genera: Onotoa de Laubenfels, 1955
, Placospherastravan Soest, 2009 and PlacospongiaGray, 1867 . The three genera are characterized by different microscleres synapomorphies, present in the cortex: amphinolasters, globose spherasters and selenasters, respectively.

Plascospongia is currently composed by 11 species, most of them are recorded from Indo-West Pacific, Caribbean Sea and North Atlantic regions, P. carinata ( Bowerbank 1858 )
; P. intermediaSollas, 1888 ; P. mixtaThiele, 1900 ; P. cristataBoury-Esnault, 1973 ; P. anthosigma ( Tanita & Hoshino 1989 )
; P. decorticans ( Hanitsch 1895 )
; P. melobesioidesGray, 1867 ; P. caribicaRützler, Piantoni, Van Soest & Diaz, 2014 ; P. santodomingoaeBecking, 2013 and P. ruetzlerivan Soest, 2017 . Before the present study, only P. cristata and P. intermedia have been recorded for the Southwestern Atlantic, now in addition, P. ruetzleri and P. giseleae are registered.

The color of living specimens vary in situ , from reddish brown to dark brown, orange, cream or white. Live color is usually retained after preservation in ethanol ( Becking 2013 ). Placospongia is a geographically widely distributed genus, and in ecological aspects, most of the species are sciophilous, and can be found in coral reefs, marine lakes, mangroves and anchialine pools, the latter restricted only to P. santodomingoae ( Nichols & Barnes 2005 ; Becking 2013 ).

Molecular studies recovered Placospongia monophyletic ( Nichols & Barnes 2005 ). Few morphological differences are found to separate species due to phenotypic plasticity, but variations in spicules features such as tyle definition, tip ends and morphometric patterns, mainly related to the size between Caribbean and the Indo-Pacific species, have been observed ( van Soest 2009 ).

In this paper, a new species of Placospongia is described from the Southwest Atlantic. Placospongia ruetzleri is also recorded for the first time from Northeastern Brazil , increasing the diversity of Placospongia species
from two to four for Brazil . Additionally, an identification key for Western Atlantic species of the genus is presented.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
Sponges were collected during various surveys over the last 31 years (1982/1984/1997/2009/2011/2012/2013) in northeastern Brazil in the southern Pernambuco State coast (Cabo de Santo Agostinho) and Bahia State coast (Mata de São João, Camaçari, Salvador , Mara) (
) through free or scuba diving, and later preserved in 80 % ethanol. The samples were deposited in the Museu de História Natural da Bahia (Porifera collection, UFBA-POR) and Universidade Federal de Pernambuco (Porifera collections, UFPEPOR).

FIGURE 1. Map showing the collecting localities in Pernambuco and Bahia State of the Placospongia species
described in this study (created in QGis software). Legend: ● Placospongia ruetzleri ; ▲ Placospongia giseleae sp. nov.

Slides of dissociated spicules and perpendicular sections of skeleton for optical microscopy and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) were prepared following the protocols described by
Hajdu et al. (2011)
and were carried out in LAMUME (Jeol JSM–6610LV) and FIOCRUZ (Jeol JSM–6390LV). Thirty spicules of each category were measured. Measurements are given in micrometers (µm) and arranged in the following format (minimum–mean–maximum). Measurements are referred as length x width (megascleres) and overall diameter x centrum diameter (microscleres).

Abbreviations:UFBA —Universidade Federal da Bahia ; UFPE —Universidade Federal de Pernambuco — SEM—Scanning Electron Microscope; FIOCRUZ—Fundação Gonçalo Muniz and LAMUME—Laboratório Multiusuário de Microscopia Eletrônica/ UFBA .

tp:treatment-sec.p: Diagnosis . Placospongiidae with tylostyles as megascleres and selenasters or amphiaster-like sterrasters as primary microscleres, forming polygonal cortical crusts. Cortical plates separated by contractile ectosomal pore grooves bearing ostia and oscula. Tylostyles in tracts radiating from the base toward the surface and supporting the margins of the cortical plates. Accessory microscleres include spirasters, spherasters, and spherules (Rützler & Hooper 2000).

Material examined.Holotype . UFBA 4051 , Praia de Aratuba , Recife das Caramuanas , Vera Cruz , 13º08’S – 38º45’W , Bahia State , Brazil , 1–2 m deep, January 30, 2013 , coll. Cavalcanti, F. & Neves, E.

tp:treatment-sec.p: Diagnosis. Megascleres tylostyles I range from 650 to 1200 µm; Tylostyles II range from to 220 to 740 µm. Microscleres selenasters and acanthomicrorhabds.
Ecology. Encrusting sponges, found on the underside of rocks, at 0–20 m depths.

Distribution. Southwest Atlantic, Brazil . Recorded from Northeast Brazil , Bahia State , Baía de Todos os Santos (Vera Cruz, Recife de Caramuanas, Aratuba beach) and south coast ( Baía de Camamu, Maraú, Paciência da Terra). Pernambuco State , south coast (Cabo de Santo Agostinho, Praia Enseada dos Corais).

Etymology . The specific epithet is dedicated to Dr. Gisele Lôbo Hajdu, for her important contribution in teaching/guiding dozens of biology students from South America and Europe since the 90’s, in phylogeography, ecology, taxonomy and molecular biology of sponges.

Remarks.Placospongia giseleae sp. nov. is similar to the Pacific species P. santodomingoae , because of the similar spicule categories, showing tylostyles I with blunt ends and tylostyles II with hastate ends like and microscleres selenasters and acanthomicrorhabds are present. Nevertheless, the new species is unique by tylostyles I having twice the size (860–1033.5–1200/7.5–11.9–15µm) in comparison to the Pacific species (430–605.5–660/13– 15.5–20 µm). In addition, in P. giseleae sp. nov. ,
tylostyles II are considerably longer (220–402.9–740 / 5–6.9–10 µm), when compared to tylostyles II of P. santodomingoae (240–290/5–8 µm).

Microrhabds are considerably smaller in Brazilian species (6–9.1–11/2–2.2–3 µm), than in P. santodomingoae (8–12.3–18/2.5–2.7–3.5 µm) ( Table 1 ). Selenasters measurements are also different, in the new species 35–59.5– 71/22–45.1–52 µm, being approximately the minimum size of the Pacific species (80–84.8–90/60–67.3–75µm).

Besides the morphological differences between these two species P. giseleae sp. nov. is found at coral reefs from tropical regions, while P. santodomingoae is exclusively found in anchialine pools from Indonesia . Therefore, the considerable distance between the Southwestern Atlantic and the Indo-Pacific Ocean, gives further evidence of specific distinctness, considering the limited dispersal ability of this genus ( Nichols & Barnes (2005) .

The differences between the species recorded to the Caribbean Sea and the new species are mainly related to additional microscleres: (1) P. caribica presents spherasters, spirasters and oxyasters; (2) P. melobesioides shows spherules; (3) P. intermedia has spherasters and spirasters; (4). Furthermore, P. ruetzleri and the Brazilian species P. cristata has as additional microscleres, spirasters and spherasters, respectively. P. giseleae sp. nov. differs from all previous species by having only selenasters and acanthomicrorhabds as microscleres in spicule composition.

). Brown color in life. Firm consistency, non-compressible sponges. Oscules not observed.
Substratum, depth range and ecology. Encrusting rocky substratum in the intertidal zone, or subtidal to < 10 m deep.

Distribution. Southwest Atlantic. Originally described from Suriname and the Guyana Shelf ( Van Soest, 2017 ). In the present study, it is recorded for the first time from Brazil : Pernambuco State (Cabo de Santo Agostinho, Praia Enseada dos Corais), Bahia State (Camaçari: Northern coast, Todos os Santos Bay: Salvador , Praia Farol da Barra: central region and Baía de Camamu: Ilha da Pedra Furada).

Remarks.P. ruetzleri was originally described from the Guyana shelf, in French Guyana and was reported from Florida, Jamaica , Grenada , Colombia and NE Brazil ( van Soest, 2017 ). However, this Brazilian record was considered doubtful due to insufficient information ( van Soest, 2017 ). In the present study, we confirm its occurrence to northeastern Brazil .

InSuriname , this species was found in sandy bottom and in murky waters with muddy bottom at 25–34 m depths, the occurrence of sponges in this type of substrate is considered rare ( van Soest 2017 ). Brazilian species of P. ruetzleri are recorded for intertidal reef environments, composed by sandy sediments at 0–10 m depths
.

Although the specimens from Brazil and from Suriname come from environments with distinct features (high turbid waters, and muddy bottoms in Suriname ), the samples of these two regions contain the same spicular categories, with presence of unique spirasters with spines disposed exclusively at the convex side of the microsclere. In the Brazilian specimens, here described, the spirasters can be sparsely spined or, more rarely, densely spined.

However, this Brazilian record was considered doubtful due to insufficient information ( van Soest, 2017 ). In the present study, we confirm its occurrence to northeastern Brazil .

InSuriname , this species was found in sandy bottom and in murky waters with muddy bottom at 25–34 m depths, the occurrence of sponges in this type of substrate is considered rare ( van Soest 2017 ). Brazilian species of P. ruetzleri are recorded for intertidal reef environments, composed by sandy sediments at 0–10 m depths
.

Although the specimens from Brazil and from Suriname come from environments with distinct features (high turbid waters, and muddy bottoms in Suriname ), the samples of these two regions contain the same spicular categories, with presence of unique spirasters with spines disposed exclusively at the convex side of the microsclere. In the Brazilian specimens, here described, the spirasters can be sparsely spined or, more rarely, densely spined.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Several Placospongia studies, including some performed in Brazil ( Boury-Esnault 1973 ; Hajdu et al., 2011 ), used light microscopy only, which hampers the identification and differentiation of the species encountered. The use of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) in our study was essential to distinguish between different morphologies of the microscleres (particularly spirasters and microrhabds), that are herein reaffirmed as the most diagnostic character within Placospongia .

This detailed analysis is useful in the taxonomic identification of Brazilian and Caribbean species with disjunct distributions, such as P. carinata ( Bowerbank, 1858 )
and P. melobesioides . Similarly to what was mentioned by Ribeiro & Muricy (2004) for the genus Tethya , the diversity of Placospongia species
in the Brazilian coast also has been largely underestimated, probably due to general faunistic surveys or rapid assessment methods that are inefficient in sampling small, rare, and cryptic species, as well as the vast geographical extent of the coastal region.

Prior to this study, there were only two species recorded for the Brazilian coast, now this has increased to four. We believe that directed field work conduced for cryptic sponge species, as those responsible for collecting specimens described herein, and the description of microscleres using SEM analysis, are decisive for an appropriate diversity estimation in Placospongia .
